security: Revealing the details of covert operations, such as airdrops to anti-Castro forces, could jeopardize those operations and endanger the individuals involved. Specifically, the mention of quantities of weapons (pistols, submachine guns, bazookas) picked up by the GOC and anti-Castro forces, and the division of recovered arms among different groups like UNIDEN, could expose sources and methods. Quoting directly: "AMYUMS REPORTED GOC PICKED UP-FOLL: 23 PISTOLS, 6 SUBMACHINE GUNS AND ONE BAZOOKA...REMAINDER CARGO BELIEVED IN HANDS ANTI CASTRO FORCES...SALE (FNU) PACHECO, LEADER UNIDEN GROUP, RECOVERED SIZABLE QUANTITY WHICH HE DIVIDED WITH (FNU) MESA."
summary: A priority cable reports on the aftermath of a failed airdrop to anti-Castro forces in the Escambray region of Cuba, detailing the recovery of weapons by both the Government of Cuba (GOC) and various anti-Castro groups.
summary_one_paragraph: This priority cable, dated November 15, 1950, discusses the results of an airdrop intended to supply anti-Castro forces in the Escambray mountains of Cuba. The cable indicates that some of the dropped weapons, including pistols, submachine guns, and a bazooka, were recovered by the Government of Cuba (GOC), while the remaining cargo is believed to be in the hands of anti-Castro groups, including Sale Pacheco's UNIDEN group and FNU Mesa. Despite the failed drop, AMYUMS reports a positive morale effect on the Escambray fighters and notes successful drops by AKHAWK to Evelio Duque's forces.
title: Report on Airdrop to Anti-Castro Forces
